https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/egi:10XKD463LW2/MAIN/application/pdf/e3d20bb07b6d56eeda18129fbf3d9283/am.pdf am am.pdf pdf false 1624051 AAM-PDF MCAT 113539 113539 S2468-8231(23)00622-3 10.1016/j.mcat.2023.113539 Fig. 1 (a-b) Top and side views of PMA cluster in its optimized configuration. Color code: Oc, green; Ob, red; Mo, dark cyan, P, pink. The measured bond lengths of Obri–Obri, Mo-Obri, Mo–Oc, and P–O are 2.47, 1.95, 1.70 & 1.55 Å, respectively. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) Binding energies of 3d non-noble metal (NNM1 = Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Co1, Ni1, Cu1, and Zn1) atoms on the PMA cluster calculated as binding energies. (b) The relation b/w the Bader charge and binding energy of NNM1 atoms adsorbed on the PMA surface. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 CO (red), O2 (green), and O2CO (blue) adsorption energies (Ead in eV) on NNM1/PMA (NNM1 = Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Co1, Ni1, Cu1, and Zn1) cluster at 4 fold hollow site. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Top and side views of the optimized structure of Co1 adatom attached on PMA (Co1/PMA). (b) CDD, blue (green) isosurface indicates charge depletion (accumulation) areas. CDD contour values are ±0.05 a.u. (c) PDOS proposed on Co1–3d (red), Co1–4s (green) and O-2p (blue) states. The EF is fixed at zero. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) The computed structure of CO anchored on Co1/PMA cluster via end-on configurations. (b) CDD, blue (green) isosurface indicates charge depletion (accumulation) areas. Catalytic mechanisms, micro-kinetic and thermodynamics studies of Phosphomolybdic acid (PMA) supported non-noble metal (NNM1 = Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Co1, Ni1, Cu1, and Zn1) single-atom catalysts (SACs) are explored for carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation by using DFT calculations. The results reveal that Co1/P1Mo12O40 have demonstrated excellent ability to adsorb (CO, O2) molecules, resulting in significant charge transfer from the catalyst surface to the adsorbate, which is essential to produce CO2 under normal reaction conditions. The various reaction pathways, including Eley Rideal (ER), Langmuir Hinshelwood (LH), Termolecular Eley Rideal (TER), and Mars Van Krevelen (MvK) are explored for CO oxidation on Co1/P1Mo12O40 to authenticate the most auspicious reaction mechanism. The energy barrier for the TER mechanism was 0.41 eV, lower as compared to the other reported materials which suggests that the Co1/P1Mo12O40 SACs would be the most appropriate future material for CO oxidation. To further validate the results, we performed the microkinetic investigation which predicts the CO oxidation rate of 4.58 × 106 s − 1. The key role of spin-magnetic moment for the promotion of CO oxidation by using Co1 single-atom catalyst was revealed from the deep electronic analysis. The current results would provide appreciated guidelines for experimentalists to develop less expensive and more effective non-noble metal SACs for CO oxidation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO oxidation First-principles calculations Phosphomolybdic acid (PMA) Single atom catalyst Termolecular Eley-Rideal mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide (CO) is a hazardous gas produced by the use of fossil fuels, industrial processes [1], insufficient fuel incineration [2], vehicle exhaust [3] and incomplete hydrocarbon combustion, which makes the environment polluted for living being [4]. CO, a silent killer, is a non-irritating, odorless, tasteless, and highly poisonous gas [5–7] that robs our hearts and brains if inhaled in huge concentration for a long time [8–10]. Catalytic oxidation of CO has attained considerable interest during the last decade due to its significance in resolving environmental global issues aroused with CO production [11–14]. The selective oxidation of CO at low temperatures is integral to several central industrial processes, such as proton exchange in the fuel cell membrane, automotive emission control, and water gas shift reaction [15–17]. High activation energy is required to convert CO into CO2 through non-catalytic methods that are not kinetically favorable [18]. Previous investigations on naked noble metals (Pt [19], Pd [20], Au [21,22] and Rh [13]) have shown that these metals could effectively catalyze CO oxidation. However, noble metals (rhodium, gold, palladium, and platinum) are expensive and sensitive to impurities. Thus, their practical implementation is hindered on an industrial scale [23,24]. Therefore, there is a dire need to develop an inexpensive non-noble metal catalyst for CO oxidation that works at low temperatures and gives efficient results at a low cost to reduce environmental pollution. Furthermore, it is a remaining challenge to lower the quantity of metal catalysts utilized for CO catalytic oxidation. In the last few years, much research has been done to create effective SACs for the oxidation of CO under typical reaction circumstances. Due to their high economic value [25], unusual catalytic activity and selectivity [25,26] and future use in fuel processing, chemical synthesis, and environmental remediation [27,28], SACs have drawn a lot of attention. Qiao et al., in 2011, introduced the concept of a single-atom catalyst. Their research revealed that SACs with Pt attached to a Fe2O3 surface demonstrated good catalytic efficiency for CO oxidation under typical reaction conditions [29]. SACs are employed in numerous industrially important reactions, such as photochemical [30], electrochemical [31] and thermochemical [32] conversions because of its special geometrical and electrical characteristics, which allow for 100% atom usage [33]. Choi and colleagues explain how SACs affect the mechanics of electrochemical CO2 reduction processes and look at advances in synthesis and analysis methods [34]. Salah et al., synthesized palladium supported on titanium carbide nano particles which exhibited good physicochemical properties and excellent CO oxidation activity [35]. Li et al., predicted that the Co-anchored on Mo2CS2 surface (Co1/Mo2CS2) SAC shows excellent catalytic activity toward CO oxidation reaction under standard reaction conditions [14]. SACs offer the maximum atom efficiency with 100% metal dispersion, a potential approach for creating affordable noble and non-noble metal catalysts [36]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are oxo-bridged polynuclear transition metals (W, Mo, Nb, Ta, and V) hetero-poly acids which demonstrate high stability and well-defined structure having fascinating physical and chemical properties [23,37]. Phosphomolybdic acid (H3PMo12O40;PMA) consists of a variety of bare oxygen (O) atom coordination sites which proved effective transition-metal (TM1) atom support for trapping. Keggin-like PMA structure has oxygen (O), molybdenum (Mo), and phosphorus (P) atoms [37,38]. The 12 MoO6 octahedral units are double bonded with 24 bridging and 12 corner oxygen atoms in PMA. It has 36 exposed oxygen that offer various coordination positions, making PMA a perfect material for allowing adsorbed single-metal atoms to be firmly bonded in multiple positions. Thus, due to its unique features, PMA has attained exceptional consideration to construct extremely effective electro-catalysts in energy storage and environmental pollution remediation [39]. Noble-metal such as Pt and Au have been proven effective for CO oxidation in several earlier investigations [24,40,41]. Recently, Talib et al., described theoretically that single Fe1 atom anchored on Phosphotungstic acid (PTA) support has good stability, high binding energies and excellent catalytic efficiency for epoxidation reaction of ethylene [42]. Yu and co-workers reported that PMA-supported SACs could activate the adsorbed O2, the coupling of 3d of the metal and 2p of O2 was responsible for electron transfer via LH mechanism and led to 2pπ* orbitals of O2 being occupied by the catalyst M1/PMA [43]. Wang et al., theoretically indicate that a series of transition metals (Co, Fe, Cu, Ni, Ru, Rh, Ag, Pd, Os, Ir, Au, and Pt) anchored on PMA cluster have very good stability. Compared to the other widely used metal oxide supports, their higher binding energies signify that they are appropriately stable to prevent accumulation [44]. Encouraged by the studies mentioned above, we used first-principles calculations to examine the non-noble metal single-atom catalyst NNM1/PMA (NNM1 = Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Co1, Ni1, Cu1 and Zn1) for CO oxidation. Our computational analysis shows that Co1/PMA is a potentially more effective, reasonably priced, and economically viable catalyst for the oxidation of CO. 2 Computational details The DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna ab-initio simulation software version 5.4.4, which included computational investigations for the geometry optimization and energy intentions [45,46]. The interaction between the core and valence shell electrons were explained with the projector-augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials [47,48]. Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functionals were used in these calculations with generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [49,50]. The Kohn-Sham orbitals are extended utilizing plane-wave basis sets with 400 eV cutoff energy. To prevent the interaction between the nearby periodic images, a vacuum space of 20 Å was chosen. The Γ point 1 × 1 × 1 was utilized for external Brillouin zone integration and k-point 3 × 3 × 3 was used for sampling the Brillouin zone but no distinct difference observed between both sampling. The convergence criteria for the geometry optimization was set at 10−5 eV for the total energy. The ions are allowed to relax till their maximum force is less than 0.02 eV/Å. Bader's quantum theory considered to calculate electron charge transfer [51,52]. Following thermodynamics convention, the Co1 atom binding energy on PMA was explained as: (1) E b [ M ] = E tot [ M / PMA ] − E [ PMA ] − E [ M ] The following equation was used to determine adsorbate's (X) adsorption (Eads) energy. (2) E ads = E tot [ X … M / PMA ] − E [ M / PMA ] − E ( X ) Thus, Etot [X… M/PMA], E [M/PMA], and E(X) represent the whole adsorption energy of the system X… M/PMA, and free adsorbate M/PMA (X= CO, O2, or CO2). Moreover, the co-adsorption energies of CO and O2 of were calculated as: (3) Δ E coads = E tot − E [ M / PMA ] − E [ CO ] − E [ O 2 ] To study the oxidation of CO on PMA-supported SACs, the dimer method [53] and nudged elastic band climbing image technique [54,55] were adopted to find the transition states. One imaginary vibrational frequency confirmed the transition state geometries. The ∆E = EFS – EIS and Ea = ETS – EIS were used to calculate reaction energy and reaction energy barriers or activation energy barriers respectively, where the EIS is the energy of the initial state, and ETS is the transition state and EFS is the final state. The values with negative sign exhibit the exothermic reaction and the values with positive sign shows the endothermic reaction. The value of d-band center of the Co1 single atom anchored on the PMA cluster can be calculated by using the following equation: (4) ε d = ∫ − ∞ ∞ n d ( ε ) ε d ε ∫ − ∞ ∞ n d ( ε ) d ε Where the nd signifies the d states of the Co1 single atom anchored on the PMA cluster. 3 Results and discussion PMA ion (PMo12O40 3−) was selected as a support, with non-noble metal (NNM1 = Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Co1, Ni1, Cu1, and Zn1) atoms binding with the PMA cluster to form the NNM1/PMA as SACs. The entirely optimized structure of PMA and the indigenous coordination are presented in Fig. 1 . The cubic unit cell positioned in the center of Keggin-type PMA is composed of 12-Mo atoms, 40-O atoms, and 1-P atom. Superficial oxygen atoms of the PMA cluster can coordinate in three different ways: terminal (Oc), bridging (Ob), and Keggin structure (O) at the sides. Various coordination sites on PMA exist with a four-fold resonating site (4H), two three-fold resonating sites (3H–Obri and 3H–Oc), and a bridge site (B–Oc–Obri) as depicted in Fig. S1. The bond lengths calculated for, Mo-Oc, P-O, Mo-Obri, and Obri-Obri remain 1.55, 1.70, 1.95, and 2.74 Å, respectively (Fig. 1). These outcomes are in remarkable coincidence with the previous experimental and theoretical works [38,56]. First, the single transition metal atoms anchored on the PMA support was examined. All the geometrically essential parameters, such as average bond distance, binding energy and Bader charge are depicted in Table S1. Here in, we discussed adsorptions of O2 and CO molecules on the NNM1/PMA cluster, reaction mechanisms, activation energy barriers and micro-kinetics for the CO oxidation are discussed. Finally, the micro-kinetics of CO oxidation on Co1/PMA were explained. 4 Screening NNM1/PMA catalysts for Co oxidation A series of 3d NNM1 (NNM1= Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Co1, Ni1, Cu1, and Zn1) atoms were tested to find an optimum catalytic system for CO oxidation. The 3d NNM1 preferred to be located at a twisted rectangular two-dimensional geometry on the 4H position of PMA [44], and their calculated binding energies range from −4 to −16 eV, respectively (see Table S1). The optimized configuration of 3d NNM1 atoms adsorbed at the PMA cluster are presented in Fig. S2. The binding energy of 3d NNM1 atoms with PMA cluster decreases with the increase of atomic number except for Zn1, and the order is Sc1 > Ti1 > V1 > Cr1 > Mn1 > Fe1 > Co1 > Ni1 > Zn1 > Cu1. To assess NNM1 stability on PMA clusters, the formation energies of non noble metal atoms were also calculated and compared to their binding energies (Table S1). The binding energies of NNM1 are all greater than their formation energies, suggesting that they prefer to adhere uniformly on the PMA cluster rather than aggregate. Remarkably, a significant charge transferred from NNM1 atoms to the PMA cluster, which is crucial for stabilizing 3d NNM1 atoms. Furthermore, the single metal atom's positive Bader charges indicate that it is in an oxidized state, which could increase the catalytic performance of CO oxidation. The structural properties like Bader charge examination (Fig. 2 b, and Table S1), bond length (Fig. S2), charge density difference (Fig. S3), PDOS (spin polarized partial density of states) (Fig. S4), CO adsorption (Fig. S5), O2 adsorption (Fig. S6)) analyses are carried out to get essential parameters like stability, adsorption and binding energy. According to our findings, these NNM1 atoms interact strongly with the PMA cluster at the 4H-site, leading to strong bonding with the adjacent oxygen atoms. The robust binding of these NNM1 atoms to PMA makes it the ideal candidate for synthesizing synthetically stable SACs. To identify the best catalyst for the oxidation of CO, we calculated the adsorption energies of CO and O2 on NNM1/PMA cluster under normal reaction condition. All possibilities were explored to find the most energetic configurations of each adsorbate. The adsorption energies and critical parameters of adsorbate are shown in Figs. S5 and S6 and Table S2. A comprehensive picture of the adsorbates and essential structural features are mentioned in the Supporting file (pages S9 and S10). According to the results shown in Fig. 3 and Table S2, (NNM1 = Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Ni1, Cu1, and Zn1) catalysts are not advantageous for CO oxidation because they have low co-adsorption energies (O2 + CO) compared to individual adsorption energies of O2 and CO. The Co1/PMA catalyst demonstrated significant binding ability with adsorbate, and considerable charge transfer is observed from the catalyst to the adsorbate, which is crucial for generating CO2 molecule normal reaction conditions. To estimate the catalytic execution of Co1/PMA SACs intended for CO oxidation, we examined the possible mechanisms (ER, LH, MvK and TER) under ordinary reaction conditions. 4.1 Properties of Co1/PMA The most stable and optimized geometry of Co1/PMA is presented in Fig. 4 a. As discussed earlier, the Co1 adatom preferred to locate dynamically at the utmost stable site, at 4H site of four contiguous O atoms of the PMA. The calculated binding energy of Co1 is −10.53 eV, and the average bond length between the Co1 and O atoms of PMA is 1.81 Å (see Table S1). Bader charge analysis indicates that the Co1 adatom bonded with the PMA cluster has a positive charge of +1.38 |e|. A considerable charge shift from the Co1 adatom to PMA cluster, due to covalent and ionic metal support interactions (CMSI), helps stabilize the Co1 adatom on PMA. The positive Bader charge, high oxidation state, and high chemical potential of Co1 adatom suggest that it is oxidized, which will help to accelerate the CO catalytic oxidation. To further elucidate the nature of binding between the Co1 adatom and PMA cluster, the charge density differences (CDD) plot is presented in Fig. 4b. This outcome indicates a lack of charge density around the anchored Co1 adatom which indicates charge density flows from Co1 adatom to the adjacent O atoms. The outcomes of CDD are in precise settlement with the evaluation of Bader charge. Likewise, robust interactions between the Co1 adatom and its adjacent O atoms are confirmed by PDOS projected for Co1/PMA, presented in Fig. 4c. The significant energy peak of the Co1 adatom, shown in Fig. 4c, lies around the Fermi level (EF) with constrained spin polarization. The strong covalent contact between the Co1 and O atoms at the 4H site of the PMA cluster was revealed by the mixing of the 3d of Co1 adatom and 2p orbitals of O atom. Additionally, the d orbitals close to the EF exhibit significant reactivity and might be crucial in triggering the adsorbates (CO, O2) in the catalytic cycle. 4.2 CO and O2 adsorption on Co1/PMA Effectively attaching the reactive molecules to the catalytic active sites is a prerequisite for catalyst proficiency. Therefore, the adsorption and coadsorption effects of reactant molecules (O2 and CO) on Co1/PMA cluster were first studied to understand the CO oxidation catalytic mechanism. The highly stable adsorption structures of CO and O2 were determined by analyzing various adsorption modes. Fig. 5 a depicts the most stable structure of CO on Co1/PMA cluster, where CO is positioned end-on configuration on top of the Co1 adatom. The calculated CO adsorption energy on Co1/PMA cluster was found to be −0.81 eV, lower than O2 adsorption. The intermolecular bond lengths are 1.70 Å for Co1-C and 1.16 Å for C-O that is 0.02 Å higher than that of the gas-phase CO (1.14 Å) molecule (Table S2). It indicates that the C-O bond has been reasonably activated. The Bader charge examination shows that the adsorbed CO gains 1.85 |e| from the Co1/PMA cluster. The CO molecule's low-lying 2π* orbital receives charge transfer from the Co1–3d orbitals, which lengthens the C-O bond (from 1.14 to 1.16 Å). Fig. 5b shows projected CDD plot of CO (ads) on Co1/PMA illustrating this electron transport behavior further. The electron density increases between the Co1 and C atoms and decreases between the Co1 and adjacent O atoms, according to the CDD plot. The primary causes of the CO molecule's adsorption on the Co1/PMA are the 5σ electrons donated to the Co1–3d orbitals and the back-donation of the occupied Co1–3d orbitals to the low-lying CO molecule 2pπ* orbitals. PDOS was projected among the Co1–3d and 4s and CO-2p orbitals to identify the electron density transfer between the CO molecule and Co1/PMA cluster. Fig. 5c shows the significant overlap between the Co1–3d orbitals and the low-lying 2pπ* orbitals of the adsorbed CO molecule near the EF. The strong binding of the CO molecule is supported by the intense mixing of CO 2pπ* orbitals with Co1–3d orbitals close to the EF. The charge transfers and robust hybridization between the CO molecule and Co1 adatom lead to the C-O bond elongation. The adsorption of O2 on Co1/PMA cluster is also investigated where the O2 molecule is tightly bound to Co1 adatom via side-on and end-on configurations. The energetically stable configuration of O2 on Co1/PMA cluster are presented in Fig. 6 a and d, with adsorption energy of −0.90 and −0.05 eV (exothermic). The interatomic bond lengths for Co-O and O-O are 2.15 and 1.30/1.25 Å, respectively. However, the bond distance of the adsorbed O2 greatly increases (1.30 (side-on) and 1.25 (end-on) Å), as compared to the gas-phase O2 (1.23 Å), indicating that O2 (side-on configuration) might be seen as superoxide (O2 −). The O2 molecule gains −0.18ǀeǀ (side-on) and −0.15ǀeǀ (end-on) from the Co1/PMA and is substantially initiated for further reaction, according to the Bader charge investigation. Due to the significant O-O bond stretching and the initiation of O2 into a superoxide (O2 −) ligand, the electron density shifts from the Co1–3d to the 2π* antibonding orbital of O2. As a result, substantial charge transfers from Co1/PMA to the O2 molecule. We also measured the CDD plot of the O2 on Co1/PMA, as presented in Fig. 6b and e, to understand the behavior of electron transfers. The Co1 and O2 molecules are covered with green charge density accumulation areas, which confirms the electron transfer from Co1/PMA to O2. According to the proposed CDD, a significant amount of charge moves from the Co1/PMA cluster to the O2 molecule. The spare charge accumulate between the O-O bond and the filled the O2 2pπ* antibonding molecular orbital, as a result the O-O bond elongated. Additionally, the localized Co1–3d and 4s and O2–2p orbitals in the calculated PDOS confirm this assumption (Fig. 6c and f). The PDOS shows a significant decline of the O-O bond and suggests that CO oxidation through the activation of an O2 molecule makes clear the strong hybridization between Co1–3d orbitals and the O2 2p orbital near to the EF. Consequently, the powerful interaction of the O2 2p orbital with the Co1–3d orbitals certifies the metal center's ability to bind. The decrease of the O-O bond and the high adsorption of O2 molecule on the Co1/PMA cluster are caused by the partially occupied 2pπ* antibonding orbital of O2. From the overhead description, it is clear that O2 adsorption is more practical and desirable than CO adsorption on the Co1/PMA cluster. Furthermore, the coadsorption of the second CO or O2 molecules on the dynamic site will significantly impact the subsequent reaction pathway when a CO molecule is pre-adsorbed on Co1/PMA. The highly stable coadsorption configuration of 2CO and CO+O2 molecules on Co1/PMA is presented in Fig. S9a, b, where the O2 molecule adsorbs with an end-on configuration on Co1/PMA cluster. The binding energies of coadsorption are −1.26 eV for two CO molecules and −1.06 eV for CO+O2 molecules, respectively, on Co1/PMA. The coadsorption energies of 2CO molecules are higher than those of O2+CO and the individual CO (−0.81 eV) and O2 (−0.90 eV) molecules, signifying that the coadsorption is more appropriate. Fig. S9c and d show the CDD of 2CO and CO+O2 molecules on Co1/PMA. The CDD exhibits a significant charge density accumulated between adsorbed 2CO and CO+O2 molecules and Co1 adatom. The computational results show that 2CO molecules coadsorption through C atoms on Co1/PMA is dynamically preferred configuration, as presented in Fig. S9a. 4.3 Mechanism of Co oxidation on Co1/PMA In our study, we examined the Eley-Rideal (ER), Langmuir Hinshelwood (LH), Termolecular Eley Rideal (TER), and Mars Van Krevelen (MvK) mechanisms to analyze a plausible mechanism for the oxidation of CO by an O2 molecule. 4.3.1 Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism In the ER pathway, the computed potential energy surface and the optimized structures, such as the initial structure (IS1-ER), transition states (TS1-ER, TS2-ER), intermediate state (IM1-ER), final state (FS1-ER) and energy profile are illustrated in Fig. 7 . The result reveals that the O2 has more robust interactions with the Co1/PMA surface compared with CO. The preadsorption of O2 on the surface of Co1/PMA is suitable for starting CO oxidation through ER mechanism. As demonstrated in (Fig. 7 ISI-ER), the first stage involves a physically adsorbed CO molecule interacting with a pre-adsorbed O2 molecule on the Co1/PMA cluster to create an intermediate that resembles to OCOO or CO3 molecule via the ER mechanism, where the both oxygen atoms of O2 molecules attached to the Co1/PMA cluster and their average bond lengths of Co1-O is 1.92 Å. In the IS1-ER, the O2 molecule acquires a side-on orientation with an O-O bond length of 1.29 Å. (superoxide), thus, the O2 (ads) is sufficiently initiated for the CO-aided, thereby facilitating the O-O bond dissociation. In the catalytic reaction (IS1-ER), a new C-O bond forms as the CO reaches the activated pre-adsorbed O2 molecule on Co1/PMA, while the O-O bond elongates from 1.29 Å to 1.56 Å (superoxide to peroxide). As a result, OCOO intermediate (IM1-ER) is formed via transition state (TS1-ER) with an energy barrier of 0.77 eV (IS1-ER → IM1-ER). A single imaginary frequency of 152i cm−1, related to the formation of C-O bonds and the cleavage of the O-O bond used to confirm the TS1-ER. In the last-step, the dissociation of OCOO IM1-ER generates a CO2 through the TS2-ER, leaving an atomic Oa on the Co1/PMA (FS1-ER). There is an exothermic reaction leading to the formation of CO2, with ΔE = −2.71 eV concerning the FS1-ER, and a reaction barrier of 0.66 eV. A single imaginary frequency of 186i cm−1 was used to confirm the TS2-ER, that is related to the dissociation of O-C bond. The newly formed CO2 molecule in FS1-ER interacts weakly with the atomic Oa sitting on the surface of Co1/PMA. Thus, it would be desorbed efficiently from Co1/PMA cluster, resulting in a free surface covered with Oa that could be used for another CO oxidation reaction. The rate constant k for ER mechanism on the Co1/PMA surface when it is subjected to temperature 298.15 K is 3.76 × 100, for CO + O2*→ OOCO* and 2.72 × 102 for OOCO* → CO2 + O*. 4.3.2 Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) The energy profile and optimized configuration of the LH mechanism, including the starting (IS2), transition (TS3, TS4), intermediate (IM2), and final (FS2) states are shown in Fig. 8 . The computed coadsorption energy of CO and O2 molecules on Co1/PMA is −1.06 eV, which is significantly greater than the individual adsorption energies of O2 (−0.90 eV) and CO (−0.81 eV). It implies that O2 and CO coadsorption is more practical. The initial state (IS2-LH) is chosen as the most probable configuration for CO and O2 molecules to coadsorb on the Co1/PMA in order to further oxidize CO. In the IS2-LH configuration, the Co1 atom has a bond distances of 1.82 Å from C atom of the CO molecule and 2.06 Å from one oxygen atom of O2 molecule (see Fig. 8). The C-O bond distance decreased to 1.13 Å, whereas the O-O bond length increased to 1.25 Å. Adsorbed CO interacts with O2 (ads) molecule to produce a peroxide-like (OCOO) intermediate (IM2-LH) via the transition state TS3-LH with a 0.52 eV activation energy barrier. In this case, TS3-LH was confirmed through an imaginary frequency of 390i cm−1, that corresponds to the formation of the C-O bond with a 1.34 Å bond length. After the IM2-LH, the catalytic dissociation initiated as follow. CO* + O2* → OCOO* OCOO* → CO2 + O* The successive breakage of O-O bond of the OCOO intermediate (IM2-LH) results in the liberation of a CO2 molecule and atomic oxygen adhering on the Co1/PMA cluster with a 0.47 eV (TS4-LH) activation energy barrier. In this process, the C-O bond is formed with energy release of 2.33 eV (FS2-LH). It was deep-rooted that the TS4-LH has an imaginary frequency of 760i cm−1, that leads to the breakage of the O-O bond and formation of the C-O bond. The CO2 molecule is removed finally, but the atomic oxygen atom (Oa) is still attached to the Co1/PMA cluster for another CO oxidation reaction. The TS3 and TS4 have reasonable activation energy barriers for CO oxidation at standard reaction conditions. The rate constant k for LH pathway on Co1/PMA cluster when it subjected to temperature 298.15 K is 6.33 × 104 s − 1 for CO* + O2* → OCOO* and 4.49 × 105 s − 1 for OOCO* → CO2 + O*. The second CO oxidation: O* + CO → CO2: When the first CO2 molecule discharges, the Oa atom leaves on top of the Co1/PMA with a Co1-O bond distance of 1.62 Å. Through the second ER2 pathway, the remaining atomic Oa oxidizes the second CO molecule. CO molecules interact with the remaining Oa atom as they approach the surface. Fig. 9 shows the reaction energy profile and optimized configurations (IS3, TS5 and FS3) of the second ER2 mechanism. The basic (IS3-ER2) structure is a physisorbed CO molecule with a parallel configuration over a preadsorbed Oa on the Co1/PMA. The CO molecule react with the preadsorbed Oa atom on Co1/PMA to form the second CO2 molecule (FS3-ER2) via TS5-ER2 and the catalyst is recuperated. The Co1-O a bond is lengthened to 1.98 Å, while the Oa-C bond is shrunk to 2.48 Å. The activation barrier for TS5-ER2 is 0.40 eV. The TS5-ER2 has an imaginary frequency of 346i cm−1 comparable to the formation of the C-O bond and the dissociation of the Co1-O bond. The rate constant k of ER2 mechanism on the Co1/PMA cluster, when subjected to temperature 298.15 K, is 6.76 × 106 s − 1 for O* + CO → CO2. 4.3.3 Termolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanisms A Termolecular Eley-Rideal mechanism has been invesrtiaged for CO oxidation on graphene-embedded Pd [55] and Co [56] catalysts. The termolecular mechanism's reaction energy profile and the configurations of IS4, IM3, TS6, TS7 and FS4 is represented in Fig. 10 . Surprisingly, the coadsorption of 2CO molecules (−1.26 eV) on the Co1/PMA cluster is stronger than the isolated CO (−0.81 eV) and O2 (−0.90 eV), taken as a primary structure (IS4-TER). In IS4-TER, a physiosorbed O2 molecule drifts above the two pre-adsorbed molecules of CO on the Co1/PMA surface. Physisorbed O2 molecules are activated by the coadsorbed 2CO molecules, resulting in the development of OCO-Co1-OCO intermediate (IM3-TER with pentagonal ring configuration) via the TS6-TER. The TS6-TER has 0.13 eV activation energy barrier (TS6-TER, imaginary frequency 495i cm−1) and has an exothermic reaction of −0.37 eV. The distance among two freshly formed C-O bonds (between the C and the physisorbed O2 molecule) gradually decreased, and the O-O bond was lengthened from 1.23 to 1.47 Å (peroxide). Successively, the O-O bond of intermediate IM3-TER (OCO−Co1−OCO) dissociates into two molecules of CO2 (FS4-TER) through the transition state (TS7-TER), with 0.41 eV activation energy barrier, (TS7-TER imaginary frequency 419i cm−1) and an exothermic reaction energy of −5.54 eV. In the TER mechanism, this step (OCOOCO*→ 2CO2) is the rate limiting step. It is evident from comparing these data that all of the activation barriers for the transition states (TS6-TER and TS7-TER) are precise for the CO oxidation process. The freshly formed CO2 fragments can be easily desorbed into the air at normal reaction conditions because the formed CO2 adsorption energy is so low. The Co1/PMA cluster has been remodeled and is ready for the next catalytic cycle. The rate constant k of TER on the Co1/PMA cluster when subjected to temperature 298.15 K is 2.47 × 1011 s − 1, for 2CO* + O2 → OCOOCO* and 4.58 × 106 s − 1 for OCOOCO*→ 2CO2. 4.3.4 Mars Van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism Zhang et al., proposed MvK mechanism for CO oxidation on Rh1 SAC supported by Phosphotungstic acid. Instead of the gas phase, they found that the oxygen atoms assisted by the catalyst [39]. Here in, the Ob or Oc atom of the PMA cluster neighboring to the Co1 sites should be the active oxygen species for the MvK mechanism. This indicates that the PMA creates an oxygen vacancy by the oxidation of CO, filled by O2 dissociative adsorption. Fig. 11 displays the energy profile and computed structures of the IS5, IM4, TS8, TS9, and FS5. A lattice oxygen atom and CO react to form CO2 (Olattice + CO→ CO2) on PMA. To find the feasibility of MvK pathway on Co1/PMA, CO oxidation was performed. In first step (IS5-MvK), the adsorbed CO approaches the oxygen lattice (Olattice) of PMA to produce CO2 (CO + Olattice→ CO2). The resultant activation energy barrier (TS8-MvK) and endothermic reaction energy for the IS5-MvK → IM4-MvK are 1.99 and 0.18 eV. Respectively. The imaginary frequency of the TS8-MvK is 389i cm−1, which represents the bond interaction among the Olattice of PMA and C atom of the adsorbed CO molecule. The Olattice is easily removed from the Co1/PMA cluster to create an oxygen vacancy (IM4-MvK). The surface oxygen vacancy (Ovac), will then be refilled in the following step by O2 adsorption and binding with a second CO molecule adsorbed on Co1/PMA to form an unstable zigzag [C-O*]-[O-O*] transition state with a relative energy of −1.70 eV and energy barrier of 1.60 eV (TS9-MvK imaginary frequency 478i cm−1). Because of the larger activation energy barrier, CO oxidation on the Co1/PMA via MvK mechanism is both thermodynamically and kinetically less favorable. The above discussion reveals that the highest activation energy (Ea) barrier was observed in case of MvK (1.99 eV) mechanism which suggest that it is not favorable for CO oxidation on Co1/PMA catalyst. The ER (0.77 eV) and LH (0.52 eV) mechanisms has comparatively low activation energy barriers than MvK mechanism and can be considered for CO oxidation. The TER mechanism is most favorable for CO oxidation as compared with LH, ER and MvK mechanisms due to lowest activation energy barriers (0.41 eV). The CO oxidation process by using TER mechanism can also be explained by spin magnetic moments. The Co1/PMA cluster has a spin-magnetic moment of 1.63 μB at the Coδ+ active center. According to the calculation the Co1/PMA cluster has a spin-magnetic moment of 1.63 μB at the Coδ+ active center. When an O2 molecule is adsorbed on the Co1/PMA surface, the magnetic moment of Coδ+ is 0.98 μB, the electrons are transferred from Coδ+ to O2 to form O2 −(superoxide). When CO was chemically adsorbed on the Co1/PMA, the magnetic moment of Coδ+ decreased from 1.63 μB to 1.15 μB. The magnetic moment of Coδ+ is decreased to 0.75 μB, when O2 is physiosorbed over the preadsorbed two CO-Co1/PMA in IS4-TER, suggesting that Coδ+ is reduced. The O2 and 2CO-Co1/PMA interact strongly, resulting in a spin-magnetic moment of 0.89 μB for TS6 and for 1.06 μB IM3. In TS7, the O-O is broken, as result IM3 (OCO-Co1-OCO) is dissociate into two CO2 molecules and the Coδ+ is oxidized which increased the magnetic moment up to 1.16 μB. The magnetic moments of Coδ+ in FS4 increase to 1.66 μB with the desorption of two CO2 molecules, and the Coδ+ is again oxidized. Using the predicted magnetic moment of each fundamental process involved in the oxidation of CO by TER mechanisms, it is evident that the magnetic moment changes at every stage from the beginning of the process to the release of the CO2 molecule (Table S3). To further explain the catalytic performance the partial density of states (PDOS) of the d-band center (ɛd) of the Co1 adatom and the physisorbed O2 with the two pre-adsorbed CO molecules on the Co1/PMA were calculated as publicized in Fig. S10. The d-band center depicts the strong interaction between the adsorbates and the Co1/PMA cluster. The valence electrons of Co1 adatom play a significant role in breaking and forming bonds between the Co1/PMA and adsorbates (CO, O2). Fig. S10 exhibits the robust interaction among the adsorbate molecules and Co1/PMA catalyst. The findings show that the adsorbed O2 molecule is initiated by the pre-adsorbed two CO molecules and the d-band center swings to a lower energy relative to the EF. 4.4 Microkinetic investigation for Co oxidation on Co1/PMA The rate constants k for each fundamental step in the ER, LH, MvK and TER pathways are projected with the use of transition state theory (TS) to better figure out the CO oxidation catalytic reaction on the Co1/PMA surface. (5) k = k B T h q T S q R exp [ − E a k B T ] The above equation specifies that, k B=1.3806452 × 10−23 J/K i (Boltzmann constant) h = 6.626 × 10−34 Js (Planck's constant), T = 298.15 K (absolute temperature), Ea is the activation energy, qTS is vibrational partition function for the transition state and qR is the primary phase of reactants. The vibrational partition function q can be calculated by as (6) q = 1 ∏ i = 1 V i b r a t i o n [ − exp ( − h v i k B T ) ] Here, vi represents vibrational frequency in this context. The rate constants of the rate-limiting steps for all four reaction mechanisms (ER, LH, TER, and MvK) are calculated at different temperatures are listed in Table 1 . In comparison to the LH, ER, and MvK mechanisms, the rate constants (k) of the rate-limiting step for TER mechanism is significantly larger. These findings are consistent with the DFT calculations that predict that the TER mechanism will progress more efficiently than the other mechanism. On the other hand,the rate constants for all reaction mechanisms increase with the increasing temperature suggesting that Co1/PMA can accelerate CO oxidation at higher temperatures. These results show that the production of CO2 on Co1/PMA is more advantageous both kinetically and thermodynamically. 5 Conclusion The isolated non-noble metal (NNM1= Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Co1, Ni1, Cu1, and Zn1) were embedded at four-fold hollow site on the PMA cluster. The Co1/PMA was considered as a most suitable for CO oxidation because it exhibits excellent binding (−10.53 eV) with PMA having average bond distance of 1.81 Å between Co1-O and Bader charge of +1.38|e. The CO oxidation over Co1/PMA single atom catalyst through four well-known mechanisms, ER, LH, MvK and TER were explored in detail. In Eley-Rideal mechanism, the adsorbed O2 molecule directly interacts with the physically adsorbed CO molecule on Co1/PMA with a 0.77 eV activation energy barrier as a rate-determining step (IS3-ER2 → FS3-ER2). For the LH pathway, the co-adsorption of peroxide intermediate with the activation energy barrier of 0.52 eV as a rate-determining step (CO* + O2* → OCOO*). The MvK-mechanism analysis also shows that the energy barrier of 1.99 eV, which is too high than other mechanisms which suggest that the MvK mechanism is not feasible. In the TER pathway, an intermediate OCO-Co1-OCO (like a pentagonal ring) is formed by a physio-adsorbed O2 molecule initiated by two chemo-adsorbed CO molecules. Finally, intermediate [OCO-Co1-OCO(ad) → 2CO2(gas)] dissociates into two carbon dioxide molecules with activation energy barrier of 0.41 eV as the rate-determining step. The investigation of CO oxidation mechanisms on Co1/PMA SAC conclude that the TER (0.41 eV) mechanism with a lower activation barrier is thermodynamically more suitable as compared with ER (0.77 eV), LH (0.52 eV) and MvK (1.99 eV) mechanisms. Furthermore, the microkinetic analysis for CO oxidation on Co1/PMA SAC shows good CO oxidation rates comparatively excellent for TER mechanism at different temperature. Based on these theoretical outcomes, experimentalists can design NNM1 single atom catalysts for CO oxidation reactions. Credit author statement All authors contributed equally. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic mechanisms, micro-kinetic and thermodynamics studies of Phosphomolybdic acid (PMA) supported non-noble metal (NNM1 = Sc1, Ti1, V1, Cr1, Mn1, Fe1, Co1, Ni1, Cu1, and Zn1) single-atom catalysts (SACs) are explored for carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation by using DFT calculations. The results reveal that Co1/P1Mo12O40 have demonstrated excellent ability to adsorb (CO, O2) molecules, resulting in significant charge transfer from the catalyst surface to the adsorbate, which is essential to produce CO2 under normal reaction conditions. The various reaction pathways, including Eley Rideal (ER), Langmuir Hinshelwood (LH), Termolecular Eley Rideal (TER), and Mars Van Krevelen (MvK) are explored for CO oxidation on Co1/P1Mo12O40 to authenticate the most auspicious reaction mechanism. The energy barrier for the TER mechanism was 0.41 eV, lower as compared to the other reported materials which suggests that the Co1/P1Mo12O40 SACs would be the most appropriate future material for CO oxidation. To further validate the results, we performed the microkinetic investigation which predicts the CO oxidation rate of 4.58 × 106 s − 1. The key role of spin-magnetic moment for the promotion of CO oxidation by using Co1 single-atom catalyst was revealed from the deep electronic analysis. The current results would provide appreciated guidelines for experimentalists to develop less expensive and more effective non-noble metal SACs for CO oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous Co1/P1Mo12O40 single-atom catalyst for CO oxidation via termolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanism
